intro: Haplopappus venetus subsp. furfuraceus, commonly known as the hairy hawk's-beard, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads and alternate leaves. The subspecies is distinguished by its soft, hairy leaves and yellow ray florets that surround a central disk of tubular flowers. It typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. The plant has a low-growing habit with a branching stem and is often found in open, sunny areas.
